title-group.article-title: Description of a new flower fly species of the Copestylum vagum group (Diptera Syrphidae) from pristine Amazonian rainforests of Colombia and Suriname

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
The adult stage of a new flower fly species, Copestylum enriquei sp. nov. ( Diptera : Syrphidae ) is described based on a single male collected in pristine rainforest in the Amazonian region of Colombia (type-locality: Florencia, Caquetá ) and two females from a conserved forest in Suriname ( Para and Brokopondo ). Copestylum enriquei sp. nov. belongs to the C. vagum species group and is similar in appearance to Copestylum vagum (Wiedemann)
, C. musicanum (Curran)
, C. tenorium Ricarte & Rotheray
, and C. chapadensis (Curran)
from which it differs by the gena and face separated by a very broad brown vitta; scutum orange except for the wide medial vitta, which is dark and metallic, ending before the prescutellar region, with the apical margin M-shaped; tibiae dark-brown, except yellow on basal 1/4. The male genitalia of C. enriquei sp. nov. are unique and striking among the C. vagum species group, characterized by the epandrium and cercus black, contrasting with the colour of hypandrium and surstylus, which are orange; epandrium with a dorsal extension, a novel character among this species group, in addition to the L-shaped surstylus, with two pairs of rounded ridges in the dorsal edge, similar to a small deer antler in velvet. Images of type material, including photographs of male genitalia are provided. A comparison of the diagnostic characters is provided as well as modifications to the previous keys to distinguish C. enriquei sp. nov. from the other species of the C. vagum group. The species Copestylum araceorum Ricarte & Rotheray
and C. tenorium Ricarte & Rotheray
are recorded for the first time in the Amazonian rainforest in Colombia .
Key words:Eristalinae , Volucellini, Neotropics , identification key

sec.title: Resumen
sec.p:
El estado adulto de una nueva especie de moscas de las flores, Copestylum enriquei sp. nov. ( Diptera : Syrphidae ) es descrito a partir de un único macho recolectado en un bosque lluvioso prístino en la región amazónica de Colombia (Localidad tipo: Florencia, Caquetá ) y dos hembras de bosque primario de Surinam ( Para y Brokopondo ). Copestylum enriquei sp. nov. pertenece al grupo de especies C. vagum , y es similar en apariencia a Copestylum vagum (Wiedemann)
, C. musicanum (Curran)
, C. tenorium Ricarte & Rotheray
, and C. chapadensis (Curran)
de las cuales se diferencia por la gena y cara separados por una vita marrón muy ancha; escudo torácico naranja a excepción de la vita media ancha de color oscuro y metálico que termina antes de la región prescutelar, con el margen apical en forma de M; tibias marrón oscuro, excepto su 1/4 basal amarillo. La genitalia masculina de C. enriquei sp. nov. es única y sorprendente entre las especies del grupo C. vagum , caracterizada por el epandrio y los cercos negros, que contrastan con el color del hipandrio y los surestilos, que son de color naranja; epandrio con extensión dorsal, un carácter novedoso dentro de este grupo de especies, además del surestilo en forma de L, con dos pares de crestas redondeadas en el borde dorsal, similar a unas pequeñas astas de ciervo aterciopeladas. Se proporcionan imágenes del material tipo, incluyendo fotografías de la genitalia masculina. Se proporciona una comparación de los caracteres diagnósticos, así como modificaciones a las claves anteriores para distinguir C. enriquei sp. nov. de las otras especies del grupo C. vagum . Las especies Copestylum araceorum Ricarte & Rotheray
y C. tenorium Ricarte & Rotheray
son registradas por primera vez en la región Amazónica Colombiana.
Palabras claves:Eristalinae , Volucellini, Neotrópico , clave de identificación.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The diagnostic features to distinguish Copestylum from other related genera have been established by Thompson (1981) ,
Rotheray et al . (2007)
, and
Ricarte et al . (2015)
. Within Copestylum , the C. vagum group includes eighteen species: Copestylum araceorum Ricarte & Rotheray in Ricarte et al. 2015
, Copestylum bequaertiCurran, 1930 , Copestylum brevifacies ( Curran, 1926 )
, Copestylum chapadensis ( Curran, 1930 )
, Copestylum circe ( Curran, 1939 )
, Copestylum curiosum ( Curran, 1939 )
, Copestylum cyclops Ricarte & Hancock in Ricarte et al. 2015
, Copestylum flukei ( Curran, 1936 )
, Copestylum lanei ( Curran, 1936 )
, Copestylum mocanum ( Curran, 1936 )
, Copestylum musicanum ( Curran, 1930 )
, Copestylum rurale ( Curran, 1939 )
, Copestylum tenorium Ricarte & Rotheray in Ricarte et al. 2015
, Copestylum tigrinum Ricarte & Hancock in Ricarte et al. 2015
, Copestylum vagum ( Wiedemann, 1830 )
, Copestylum varichaeta ( Curran, 1925 )
, Copestylum virescens ( Williston, 1891 )
, and Copestylum willistoni Ricarte & Hancock in Ricarte et al. 2015
( Thompson 2006 ;
Ricarte et al. 2015
).

Charles Curran ( Curran 1930 , 1939 ) was the first to key out the Copestylum species
belonging to the C. vagum group, including the description of ten new species. The C. vagum group was partially reviewed by
Ricarte et al . (2015)
, including the descriptions and keys to both adult and early stages of seven species, five of which were described as new. In his study, Antonio Ricarte and collaborators suggested an apparent affinity of this group for decomposing fruits as preferred breeding sites.

The present work aims to describe a new Copestylum species
belonging to the C. vagum group from the pristine rainforest in the Amazonian region of Colombia and Suriname .A comparison of the diagnostic characters is provided as well as modifications to the previous keys to distinguish the new species from the other species of the C. vagum group.

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p:
The morphological terminology follows Cumming and Wood (2017) and
Ricarte et al . (2015)
. The type series of the new species is comprised of dry pinned specimens. The male holotype is deposited at the Colección del Laboratorio de Entomología Universidad de la Amazonia ( LEUA ), Florencia, Caquetá , Colombia . Two female paratypes are deposited in the National Museum of Natural History, Leiden (RMNH), The Netherlands . The types were collected in the lowland Amazonian rainforest of Colombia and Suriname .

To illustrate the morphological characteristics of the herein described species, habitus photographs were created from a series of high-resolution pictures taken at different focal depths using a Leica digital camera DFC450 coupled to a stereomicroscope Leica M205A and connected to a computer with Leica Application Suite software, with an automatic mounting module (synchronization software) (http://www.syncroscopy.com/syncroscopy/). Editing was conducted in Adobe Photoshop CC, and the final image plates were prepared in Illustrator CC, including the scale bar.

For morphological descriptions, adult body length was measured from the tip of the frontal prominence to the posterior end of the abdomen; wing length was measured from wing insertion to the wing apex. Measurements were made using a stereomicroscope Leica M205A equipped with a stereoscope grid.

For the study of the male genitalia, the structure was placed in lactic acid (85%) and heated at 150ºC over a Thermo Scientific Cimarec plate for approximately one hour prior to the dissection. The dissected pieces were photographed in dehydrated glycerin using an excavated slide. After examination, the dissected genitalia were stored in plastic microvials containing glycerin, pinned along with the respective specimen.

Locality and identification labels are enclosed within a double quotation (“ ”), and line breaks of the labels are separated by a forward slash (/). Handwritten information on the labels is provided in italics.

Maps of geographic distribution were plotted using the Simple Mappr software ( Shorthouse 2010 ). Pictures of type specimens of C. bequaerti , C. brevifacies , C. chapadensis , C. circe , C. curiosum , C. flukei , C. lanei , C. musicanum ,
and C. rurale are available on the AMNH website for comparison (http://research.amnh.org/invertzoo/ types _db/).
Valid names were taken from the Nomenclator of the BioSystematic Database of World Diptera and Systema Dipterorum ( Evenhuis & Pape 2020 ).

Copestylum tenorium Ricarte & Rotheray in Ricarte et al. 2015

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Diagnosis (adapted from Thompson 2006 and
Ricarte et al . 2015
). The C. vagum group can be distinguished from the other Copestylum species
groups by: 1) face vittate but not tomentose and with background colour shiny yellow, green, or orange, 2) face not particularly extended, 3) scutum with mixed length pile, not forming distinct layers and most orientated posteriorly, 4) no outstanding, long, thick setae along the rear margin of the scutum, although long pile may be present, 5) apex of the scutellum with a linear depression, 6) calypter dark, brown to black or with brown border, 7) tergum 1 and most of tergum 2 with a pale mark contrasting with the colour of the scutum, scutellum and the rest of the abdomen, and 8) male genitalia with aedeagal hood projecting ventrally from the hypandrium, superior lobe with smooth margins.

Remarks. The new species here described agrees with the diagnostic characters proposed for the C. vagum group, but can easily be recognized within this group by the unique and striking male genitalia, characterized by the epandrium and cercus black; epandrium with a dorsal extension, a novel character among the group, in addition to the surstylus L-shaped, with two pairs of rounded ridges in the dorsal edge, similar to small deer antlers in velvet.
Additional records of species of the Copestylum vagum group

New distributional records of C. tenorium and C. araceorum are here provided. Copestylum tenorium was exclusively known from Costa Rica and C. araceorum was described from material collected in Costa Rica and Ecuador . Both species are recorded for the first time in the Amazonian rainforest of Colombia .
Adjustments to existing identification keys of the C. vagum species group

The last key of Curran (1930 , 1939 ) covered most of the species included in the C. vagum group.
Ricarte et al . (2015)
partially reviewed the C. vagum group, providing a key for seven species, of which five were described as new. We provide modifications to the previous keys of the C. vagum group to distinguish C. enriquei sp. nov. from the other eighteen species included in the group. The new key is based on characters provided by Curran (1930 , 1939 ), Thompson (2006) , and Ricarte et al. (2015) , in addition to some new provided here. Images and information of type specimens of nine species (see material and methods) are available at the AMNH website.

Differential diagnosis.Copestylum enriquei sp. nov. shares the general morphological characters of other known species in the C. vagum group. Copestylum enriquei sp. nov. is a green yellowish fly, similar in appearance to C. vagum , C. musicanum , and C. tenorium , from which it differs by the gena and face separated by a very broad brown vitta; scutum orange except for the wide medial vitta, which is dark and metallic, ending before the prescutellar region, with the apical margin M-shaped; tibiae dark-brown, except yellow on basal 1/4. Epandrium and cercus black, contrasting with the colour of hypandrium and surstylus, which are orange; epandrium with a dorsal extension, in addition to the surstylus L-shaped, with two pairs of rounded ridges in the dorsal edge, similar to small deer antlers in velvet.

FEMALE (
; Reemer 2016: 100 , Fig. 15, dorsal habitus). Similar to male except for usual sexual dimorphism, and differing in vertex with a complete brownish transverse macula, extensively dark brown to blackhaired in this area; sternites 4 and 5 yellow.

Etymology. The epithet ‘enriquei’ is a patronym given in memory of Carlos Enrique Giraldo, the grandfather of the first author, a notable, worthy, and noble person of sweet spirit who was like an oak, a very happy man who taught me (ALM) to enjoy and marvel at the small things of the natural world. For him, this beautiful species that flies high as his unforgettable smile and kind way of being, always ready to provide a space and welcome in his home in Anserma, Caldas , Colombia that was always open to everyone.

Taxonomic remarks.Copestylum enriquei sp. nov. run to C. chapadensis or C. bequaerti in the key of Curran (1930 ; couplet 9, p. 6), based on the gena and face separated by a very broad brownish vitta. This work covered most species belonging to the C. vagum group. Copestylum enriquei sp. nov. would be identified as C. musicanum in an unpublished draft key by F.C. Thompson (couplet 13), as it has the tibiae much darker than the femora, terminalia large, cercus elongate, hook-like, extending over the fourth sternum. Using the key of
Ricarte et al . (2015
; couplet 3, p. 52), C. enriquei sp. nov. keys out close to C. araceorum and C. willistoni , based on the terga 3−4 with yellow marks or completely black, however, C. enriquei sp. nov. lacks a median vitta on the face. Copestylum enriquei sp. nov. is also morphologically similar to C. tenorium from which it differs by the diagnostic characters listed in Table 1 (See also “Taxonomic notes” under each species in
Ricarte et al . 2015
and keys).

Biology.Copestylum enriquei sp. nov. is only known from pristine patches in the lowlands of the Amazonian rainforest of Colombia and Suriname (
). The specimens were collected using a canopy Malaise trap and sweeping net, which could suggest that the species is associated with both canopy and ground levels in conserved forest.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: A new key to the species of the C. vagum group is provided to distinguish the new species C. enriquei sp. nov. from the other eighteen species in the group. The concept of the C. vagum group remains unaltered, increasing some novel characters concerning the highly modified genitalia of the new species, where the surstylus is unique and striking with two pairs of rounded ridges in the dorsal edge, similar to small deer antlers in velvet. The modification of the surstylus of C. enriquei sp. nov. could be associated with functional utilities in the mating process, since the surstyli is the structure that grips the female, facilitating the coupling ( Rotheray & Gilbert 2011 ). This novel morphological evidence for Copestylum could open the way to new questions about the origin, evolution, and diversification of the richest hoverfly group in the Neotropical region, Copestylum .

The distributional patterns of the C. vagum group are considerably variable. Copestylum enriquei sp. nov. (Colombian and Suriname ), C. flukei , C. lanei ( Brazil and Colombia ), C. musicanum ( Brazil and Suriname ), C. chapadensis ( Brazil , Brazilian Amazon), C. circe , C. curiosum , C. rurale ( Brazil ), C. varichaeta ( Peru ), and C. tigrinum ( Trinidad ) appear to be restricted to South America. Copestylum bequaerti ( Guatemala , Mexico ) and C. cyclops ( Costa Rica ) are only known from Central America. The group also includes widely distributed species such as C. vagum ( Brazil , Brazilian Amazon, Colombia , Costa Rica , Guyana , Less Antilles, Peru , and Suriname ), C. virescens ( Colombia , Costa Rica , Guatemala ), C. araceorum ( Colombia , Costa Rica , and Ecuador ), C. tenorium ( Colombia , Costa Rica ), and C. willistoni ( Costa Rica , Trinidad ) which extend from Central to South America. Copestylum brevifacies ( Argentina , Brazil , Guyana , Suriname ), and C. mocanum ( Colombia , Brazilian Amazon, Guatemala , Peru , Venezuela ) are exclusive and widely spread in South America.

As shown above, the C. vagum group includes narrowly and widely distributed species, with C. enriquei sp. nov. apparently restricted to lowlands in the Amazonian rainforest of Colombia and Suriname , and C. araceorum and C. tenorium are recorded for the first time in the Colombian Amazonian region. These findings could suggest an apparent lack of sampling effort in the C. vagum group so that new expeditions to unexplored areas could eventually result in the estimation of its real distributional range throughout the region.
